texts.shortText: Shell small and globular with a fairly short spire and a round, horny operculum. External colour usually pale brown with darker flecks and a darker band around centre of each whorl, but sometimes almost completely black. The unusual habitat in the uppermost parts of the intertidal is also useful identification feature.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.

A very well-known and abundant species that dominates the upper part of the intertidal on rocky shores, which is named the ‘Littorina zone’ as a result. Congregates out of water in large numbers in cracks and crevices and in any similar sheltered locations during low tide and during the heat of the day, emerging at night, or on moist days, to feed on lichens and microscopic algae on the rocks.

There is generally a size gradient within the population, with smaller individuals occurring higher on the shore to avoid severe wave action. As they grow, and are able to attach more firmly, they migrate lower on the shore, where food resources are richer.

Growth is fairly rapid, with a shell length of about 6-7 mm being attained in the first year and maximum length of about 10 mm after 3 years. Growth is slowest in winter and faster in spring or summer, probably as a result of greater food availability in the warmer months.

Can often be seen hanging from the rock surface via a sticky patch of mucus attached to the margin of the aperture, indeed may form ‘stacks’ several layers tall in this way, in an attempt to distance the body from the heat of the rocks!

At high spring tides individuals lower on the shore are often seen being consumed by the predatory dog whelk Nucella dubia, which grasps the periwinkle and drills a hole through its operculum, a process that takes several hours.
Browse on algae, diatoms and detritus on rocky substrata.

Littorinids exhibit several modes or reproduction - in some species the larvae develop inside the mantle cavity and emerge as crawling juveniles, in others egg cases are released into the plankton and in yet another benthic egg capsules are attached to algae or rock. As no egg capsules, nor brooded young, have been observed in this species it is assumed they release egg capsules into the water column. Settlement appears to take place throughout the year and sexual maturity is attained within the first year of life, at a size of about 5 mm.

The habitat – usually out of water and in the highest levels of exposed rocky shores – is fairly diagnostic and separates this species from most other small periwinkles. Progressively replaced along the south coast by the more tropical Littorina africana, which has similar habits, but is squatter in shape and blue-grey in colour, with a brown aperture.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174)

McQuaid, CD (1981a). The establishment and maintenance of vertical size gradients in populations of Littorina africana knysnaensis (Philippi) on an exposed rocky shore. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 54(1), 77-89.

McQuaid, CD (1981b). Population dynamics of Littorina africana knysnaensis (Philippi) on an exposed rocky shore. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 54(1), 65-76.

McQuaid, CD (1985). Differential effects of predation by the intertidal whelk Nucella dubia (Kr.) on Littorina africana knysnaensis (Phillipi) and the barnacle Tetraclita serrata Darwin. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 89(2-3), 97-107.
